column2: About three o'clock the four couples, frightened at their happiness, were sliding down the Russian mountains, a singular edifice which then occupied the heights of Beaujon, and whose undulating line was visible above the trees of the Champs Elysees.
column3: About three o'clock the four couples, frightened at their happiness, were sliding down the Russian mountains, a singular edifice which then occupied the heights of Beaujon, and whose undulating line was visible above the trees of the Champs Elysees.

column2: CHAPTER V--AT BOMBARDA'S
column3: CHAPTER five-AT BOMBARDA'S

column2: The Russian mountains having been exhausted, they began to think about dinner; and the radiant party of eight, somewhat weary at last, became stranded in Bombarda's public house, a branch establishment which had been set up in the Champs-Elysees by that famous restaurant-keeper, Bombarda, whose sign could then be seen in the Rue de Rivoli, near Delorme Alley.
column3: The Russian mountains having been exhausted, they began to think about dinner; and the radiant party of eight, somewhat weary at last, became stranded in Bombarda's public house, a branch establishment which had been set up in the Champs Elysees by that famous restaurant keeper, Bombarda, whose sign could then be seen in the Rue de Rivoli, near Delorme Alley.

column2: A large but ugly room, with an alcove and a bed at the end (they had been obliged to put up with this accommodation in view of the Sunday crowd); two windows whence they could survey beyond the elms, the quay and the river; a magnificent August sunlight lightly touching the panes; two tables; upon one of them a triumphant mountain of bouquets, mingled with the hats of men and women; at the other the four couples seated round a merry confusion of platters, dishes, glasses, and bottles; jugs of beer mingled with flasks of wine; very little order on the table, some disorder beneath it;
column3: A large but ugly room, with an alcove and a bed at the end (they had been obliged to put up with this accommodation in view of the Sunday crowd); two windows whence they could survey beyond the elms, the quay and the river; a magnificent August sunlight lightly touching the panes; two tables; upon one of them a triumphant mountain of bouquets, mingled with the hats of men and women; at the other the four couples seated round a merry confusion of platters, dishes, glasses, and bottles; jugs of beer mingled with flasks of wine; very little order on the table, some disorder beneath it;

column2: They made beneath the table A noise, a clatter of the feet that was abominable,
column3: They made beneath the table A noise, a clatter of the feet that was abominable,

column2: says Moliere.
column3: says Moliere.

column2: This was the state which the shepherd idyl, begun at five o'clock in the morning, had reached at half-past four in the afternoon.
column3: This was the state which the shepherd idyl, begun at five o'clock in the morning, had reached at half past four in the afternoon.

column2: The sun was setting; their appetites were satisfied.
column3: The sun was setting; their appetites were satisfied.

column2: The Champs-Elysees, filled with sunshine and with people, were nothing but light and dust, the two things of which glory is composed.
column3: The Champs Elysees, filled with sunshine and with people, were nothing but light and dust, the two things of which glory is composed.

column2: The horses of Marly, those neighing marbles, were prancing in a cloud of gold.
column3: The horses of Marly, those neighing marbles, were prancing in a cloud of gold.

column2: Carriages were going and coming.
column3: Carriages were going and coming.

column2: A squadron of magnificent body-guards, with their clarions at their head, were descending the Avenue de Neuilly; the white flag, showing faintly rosy in the setting sun, floated over the dome of the Tuileries.
column3: A squadron of magnificent body guards, with their clarions at their head, were descending the Avenue de Neuilly; the white flag, showing faintly rosy in the setting sun, floated over the dome of the Tuileries.

column2: The Place de la Concorde, which had become the Place Louis XV. once more, was choked with happy promenaders.
column3: The Place de la Concorde, which had become the Place Louis the fifteenth. once more, was choked with happy promenaders.

column2: Many wore the silver fleur-de-lys suspended from the white-watered ribbon, which had not yet wholly disappeared from button-holes in the year 1817.
column3: Many wore the silver fleur de lys suspended from the white watered ribbon, which had not yet wholly disappeared from button holes in the year eighteen seventeen.

column2: Here and there choruses of little girls threw to the winds, amid the passersby, who formed into circles and applauded, the then celebrated Bourbon air, which was destined to strike the Hundred Days with lightning, and which had for its refrain:--
column3: Here and there choruses of little girls threw to the winds, amid the passersby, who formed into circles and applauded, the then celebrated Bourbon air, which was destined to strike the Hundred Days with lightning, and which had for its refrain:--

column2: Rendez-nous notre pere de Gand, Rendez-nous notre pere.
column3: Rendez nous notre pere de Gand, Rendez nous notre pere.

column2: Give us back our father from Ghent, Give us back our father.
column3: Give us back our father from Ghent, Give us back our father.

column2: Groups of dwellers in the suburbs, in Sunday array, sometimes even decorated with the fleur-de-lys, like the bourgeois, scattered over the large square and the Marigny square, were playing at rings and revolving on the wooden horses; others were engaged in drinking; some journeyman printers had on paper caps; their laughter was audible.
column3: Groups of dwellers in the suburbs, in Sunday array, sometimes even decorated with the fleur de lys, like the bourgeois, scattered over the large square and the Marigny square, were playing at rings and revolving on the wooden horses; others were engaged in drinking; some journeyman printers had on paper caps; their laughter was audible.

column2: Every thing was radiant.
column3: Every thing was radiant.

column2: It was a time of undisputed peace and profound royalist security; it was the epoch when a special and private report of Chief of Police Angeles to the King, on the subject of the suburbs of Paris, terminated with these lines:--
column3: It was a time of undisputed peace and profound royalist security; it was the epoch when a special and private report of Chief of Police Angeles to the King, on the subject of the suburbs of Paris, terminated with these lines:--

column2: Taking all things into consideration, Sire, there is nothing to be feared from these people.	Taking all things into consideration, Sire, there is nothing to be feared from these people.
column3: true

column2: They are as heedless and as indolent as cats. The populace is restless in the provinces; it is not in Paris.
column3: They are as heedless and as indolent as cats. The populace is restless in the provinces; it is not in Paris.

column2: These are very pretty men, Sire.
column3: These are very pretty men, Sire.

column2: It would take all of two of them to make one of your grenadiers.
column3: It would take all of two of them to make one of your grenadiers.

column2: There is nothing to be feared on the part of the populace of Paris the capital.
column3: There is nothing to be feared on the part of the populace of Paris the capital.

column2: It is remarkable that the stature of this population should have diminished in the last fifty years; and the populace of the suburbs is still more puny than at the time of the Revolution.
column3: It is remarkable that the stature of this population should have diminished in the last fifty years; and the populace of the suburbs is still more puny than at the time of the Revolution.

column2: It is not dangerous.
column3: It is not dangerous.

column2: In short, it is an amiable rabble."
column3: In short, it is an amiable rabble."

column2: Prefects of the police do not deem it possible that a cat can transform itself into a lion; that does happen, however, and in that lies the miracle wrought by the populace of Paris.
column3: Prefects of the police do not deem it possible that a cat can transform itself into a lion; that does happen, however, and in that lies the miracle wrought by the populace of Paris.

column2: Moreover, the cat so despised by Count Angles possessed the esteem of the republics of old.
column3: Moreover, the cat so despised by Count Angles possessed the esteem of the republics of old.

column2: In their eyes it was liberty incarnate; and as though to serve as pendant to the Minerva Aptera of the Piraeus, there stood on the public square in Corinth the colossal bronze figure of a cat.
column3: In their eyes it was liberty incarnate; and as though to serve as pendant to the Minerva Aptera of the Piraeus, there stood on the public square in Corinth the colossal bronze figure of a cat.

column2: The ingenuous police of the Restoration beheld the populace of Paris in too "rose-colored" a light; it is not so much of "an amiable rabble" as it is thought.
column3: The ingenuous police of the Restoration beheld the populace of Paris in too "rose colored" a light; it is not so much of "an amiable rabble" as it is thought.

column2: The Parisian is to the Frenchman what the Athenian was to the Greek: no one sleeps more soundly than he, no one is more frankly frivolous and lazy than he, no one can better assume the air of forgetfulness; let him not be trusted nevertheless; he is ready for any sort of cool deed; but when there is glory at the end of it, he is worthy of admiration in every sort of fury.
column3: The Parisian is to the Frenchman what the Athenian was to the Greek: no one sleeps more soundly than he, no one is more frankly frivolous and lazy than he, no one can better assume the air of forgetfulness; let him not be trusted nevertheless; he is ready for any sort of cool deed; but when there is glory at the end of it, he is worthy of admiration in every sort of fury.

column2: Give him a pike, he will produce the 10th of August; give him a gun, you will have Austerlitz.
column3: Give him a pike, he will produce the tenth of August; give him a gun, you will have Austerlitz.

column2: He is Napoleon's stay and Danton's resource.
column3: He is Napoleon's stay and Danton's resource.

column2: Is it a question of country, he enlists; is it a question of liberty, he tears up the pavements.
column3: Is it a question of country, he enlists; is it a question of liberty, he tears up the pavements.

column2: Beware! his hair filled with wrath, is epic; his blouse drapes itself like the folds of a chlamys.
column3: Beware! his hair filled with wrath, is epic; his blouse drapes itself like the folds of a chlamys.

column2: Take care! he will make of the first Rue Grenetat which comes to hand Caudine Forks.
column3: Take care! he will make of the first Rue Grenetat which comes to hand Caudine Forks.

column2: When the hour strikes, this man of the faubourgs will grow in stature; this little man will arise, and his gaze will be terrible, and his breath will become a tempest, and there will issue forth from that slender chest enough wind to disarrange the folds of the Alps.
column3: When the hour strikes, this man of the faubourgs will grow in stature; this little man will arise, and his gaze will be terrible, and his breath will become a tempest, and there will issue forth from that slender chest enough wind to disarrange the folds of the Alps.

column2: It is, thanks to the suburban man of Paris, that the Revolution, mixed with arms, conquers Europe.
column3: It is, thanks to the suburban man of Paris, that the Revolution, mixed with arms, conquers Europe.

column2: He sings; it is his delight.
column3: He sings; it is his delight.

column2: Proportion his song to his nature, and you will see!
column3: Proportion his song to his nature, and you will see!

column2: As long as he has for refrain nothing but la Carmagnole, he only overthrows Louis XVI.; make him sing the Marseillaise, and he will free the world.
column3: As long as he has for refrain nothing but la Carmagnole, he only overthrows Louis the sixteenth.; make him sing the Marseillaise, and he will free the world.

column2: This note jotted down on the margin of Angles' report, we will return to our four couples.
column3: This note jotted down on the margin of Angles' report, we will return to our four couples.

column2: The dinner, as we have said, was drawing to its close.
column3: The dinner, as we have said, was drawing to its close.
